Name: METOBROMURON
Description: Metobromuron is a member of ureas.

environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: Predicted Bioconcentration Factor: 23, based on calculated water solubility; 3, based on calculated soil adsorption coefficient.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Briggs GG; J Agric Food Chem 29: 1050-9 (1981) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 5-4, 5-10 (1990) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF value of 38 was calculated for metobromuron(SRC), using an experimental log Kow of 2.38(1) and a recommended regression-derived equation(2). According to a recommended classification scheme(3), this BCF value suggests that bioconcentration in aquatic organisms may be moderate, not high(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: Spencer, E. Y. Guide to the Chemicals Used in Crop Protection. 7th ed. Publication 1093. Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, Ottawa, Canada: Information Canada, 1982., p. 232
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ... The two fungi, Talaromyces wortmanii and Fusarium oxysporum metabolized (14)C-labeled metobromuron, whereas a Bacillus sp and the alga Chlorella vulgaris were unable to degrade the same herbicide.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Spencer, E. Y. Guide to the Chemicals Used in Crop Protection. 7th ed. Publication 1093. Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, Ottawa, Canada: Information Canada, 1982., p. 240
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Talaromyces wortmanii and Fusarium oxyporum degrade metobromuron by N-demethoxylation.

environmental_biodegradations.References: Spencer, E. Y. Guide to the Chemicals Used in Crop Protection. 7th ed. Publication 1093. Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, Ottawa, Canada: Information Canada, 1982., p. 240
environmental_biodegradations.Value: /Metobromuron was incubated/ with soil-enrichment solutions and pure cultures of active microbial isolates. ... It was shown that in the presence of the fungus, Fusarium oxysporum, halogen ions were released into the culture medium from ... metobromuron.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Englehardt G et al; Appl Microbiol 22: 284-88 (1971) (2) Weinberger M, Bollag JM; Appl Microbiol 24: 750-4 (1972) (3) Hartley D, Kidd H (eds); The Agrochemicals Handbook. 2nd ed. Lechworth, Herts, England: Royal Soc Chemistry, pg 277 Oct 83 (1987) (4) Kearney PC, Kaufman DD; Herbicides: Chemistry, Degradation and Mode of Action. Vol 1 and 2. 2nd ed. NY,NY: Marcel Dekker Inc (1975)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: The degradation of metobromuron by a linuron-inducible enzyme produced by Bascillus sphaericus had a specific activity of the cell-free extract of 0.18X10-3 units/mg of protein and produced 4-bromoaniline(1). The fungus Rhizoctonia solani was able to transform metobromuron by 70% after 6 days(2). In plants, the methyl and methoxy groups are split off and the urea moiety is further degrade to 4-bromoaniline(3). Presumably there is simultaneous ring hydroxylation and fission(3). Two fungi, Talaromyces wortmanii and Fusarium oxysporum metabolized 14C-labeled metobromuron, whereas neither Bascillus sphaericus nor the alga Chlorella vulgaris were able to degrade metobromuron(4).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: Doull, J., C.D. Klaassen, and M. D. Amdur (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 2nd ed. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co., 1980., p. 641
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Metobromuron /is/ ... moderately mobile in the soil ... Movement of the cmpd also decr as organic matter content of the soil incr, and in turn the herbicidal activity of the phenylureas decr as the cmpd are bound to the soil organic matter.

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Briggs GG; J Agric Food Chem 29: 1050-9 (1981) (2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 4-9 (1990) (3) Gerstl Z, Helling CS; J Environ Sci Health B 22: 55-69 (1987) (4) Hamaker JW, Thompson JM; Organic Chemicals in the Soil Environment. Goring CAI, Hamaker JN (eds) 1: 49-144 (1972) (5) Kozak J, Weber JB; Weed Science 31: 368-72 (1983) (6) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc of metobromuron is estimated as approximately 470(SRC), using an experimental log Kow of 2.38(1) and a regression-derived equation(2,SRC). The Koc for metobromuron has also been experimentally determined to be 104.7(3). For soil with organic carbon levels of 0.58-2.3%, metobromuron had an average experimental Koc value of 60(4). The average Koc value from eight soils of Czechoslovakia with organic matter contents ranging from 0.1-4.6% was 490(5). According to a recommended classification scheme(6), this estimated Koc value suggests that metobromuron should have medium to high mobility in soil(SRC).

plant_translocations.content: Tomato ('Heinz 1350'), susceptible to both metobromuron and chlorbromuron herbicides, readily absorbed and translocated them to the foliage. Carrot ('Gold Pak') and coriander, moderately susceptible and resistant to these herbicides respectively, absorbed and translocated metobromuron but not chlorbromuron appreciably upwards. Neither herbicide, when applied to leaves, was significantly translocated in tomato or coriander. Coriander showed no appreciable metabolism of either compound. Extracts from tomato roots and tops showed significant radioactivity, indicating little metabolism. The lack of translocation of chlorbromuron to the tops of umbelliferous crops contributed to their tolerance. The differential tolerance of carrot and coriander to metobromuron compared to tomato could not be explained by differential uptake or metabolism.
plant_translocations.reference: Hogue, E. J. (1978). Absorption and translocation of metobromuron and chlorbromuron. Journal of Environmental Science & Health Part B, 13(3), 323-339.

method.Apply Location: Root application (plants grown in hydroponic solution containing radiolabeled herbicides)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seedlings initially grown in silica sand, watered with modified Hoagland's solution.At 2-5 cm height, transferred to Hoagland's solution to establish root system.At ~4 leaf stage, plants transferred to 10^-5 M metobromuron or chlorbromuron solution (10^-6 M for tomato)
method.Chemical Preparation: Uniformly 14C-labeled metobromuron on phenyl ring (0.22, 2.2 mCi/mM at 10^-5, 10^-6 M).14C-chlorbromuron labeled at carbonyl position (0.19, 1.9 mCi/mM at 10^-5, 10^-6 M)
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Seedlings exposed to radiolabeled herbicide solutions for varying time periods.Sublethal concentrations used - 10^-5 M for coriander, carrot; 10^-6 M for tomato
method.Other information and Other Information: Plant extraction for TLC analysis done using acetone/ethanol, acid hydrolysis. 4 replicates per treatment, each with 2 plants
